content.description:
“The goal of government is the good of mankind, and which is best for mankind—that the people should always be exposed to the boundless will of tyranny or that the rulers should sometimes be liable to be opposed? Upon the forfeiture of their rulers, power reverts to the society and the people have a right to act as supreme and place it in a new form or new hands, as they think good.”
John Locke, An Essay Concerning the True Origin, Extent, and End of Civil Government, 1690
content.question: The influence of the Scientific Revolution on Locke’s reasoning regarding the right of people to establish new forms of government is most clearly reflected in his

choices.label: assumption that monarchical government can devolve into tyranny
assertion that people will sometimes resist oppressive governments
implication that opposition to oppressive governments is sometimes successful
appeal to universal principles that supposedly define the function of government

content.answer: appeal to universal principles that supposedly define the function of government
